--- title: "Hands-On Exercise 4c (Visualising Uncertainty)" author: "Zanelle Lee Wenfang" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: echo: true eval: true warning: false freeze: true --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(plotly, crosstalk, DT, ggdist, ggridges, colorspace, gganimate, tidyverse) exam <- read_csv("Data files/Exam_data.csv") #derive necessary summary statistics #group_by() of dplyr package is used to group the observation by RACE, #summarise() is used to compute the count of observations, mean, #standard deviation #mutate() is used to derive standard error of Maths by RACE #output is saved as a tibble data table called my_sum my_sum <- exam %>% group_by(RACE) %>% summarise( n=n(), mean=mean(MATHS), sd=sd(MATHS) ) %>% mutate(se=sd/sqrt(n-1)) #display my_sum tibble data frame in html table format knitr::kable(head(my_sum), format = 'html') ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
RACE n mean sd se
Chinese 193 76.50777 15.69040 1.132357
Indian 12 60.66667 23.35237 7.041005
Malay 108 57.44444 21.13478 2.043177
Others 9 69.66667 10.72381 3.791438
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #plotting standard error bars of mean Math scores by race #The error bars are computed by using the formula mean+/-se #For geom_point(), it is important to indicate stat=“identity”. ggplot(my_sum) + geom_errorbar( aes(x=RACE, ymin=mean-se, ymax=mean+se), width=0.2, colour="black", alpha=0.9, linewidth=0.5) + geom_point(aes (x=RACE, y=mean), stat="identity", color="red", size = 1.5, alpha=1) + ggtitle("Standard error of mean maths score by race") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-On_Exercise_04c_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #plotting confidence intervals of mean Math score by race #confidence intervals are computed by using the formula mean+/-1.96*se #error bars is sorted by using the average maths scores #labs() argument of ggplot2 is used to change the x-axis label ggplot(my_sum) + geom_errorbar( aes(x=reorder(RACE, -mean), ymin=mean-1.96*se, ymax=mean+1.96*se), width=0.2, colour="black", alpha=0.9, linewidth=0.5) + geom_point(aes (x=RACE, y=mean), stat="identity", color="red", size = 1.5, alpha=1) + labs(x = "Maths score", title = "95% confidence interval of mean maths score by race") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-On_Exercise_04c_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #plotting interactive error bars for 99% confidence interval of mean #Math scores by race shared_df = SharedData$new(my_sum) bscols(widths = c(4,8), ggplotly((ggplot(shared_df) + geom_errorbar(aes( x=reorder(RACE, -mean), ymin=mean-2.58*se, ymax=mean+2.58*se), width=0.2, colour="black", alpha=0.9, size=0.5) + geom_point(aes( x=RACE, y=mean, text = paste("Race:", `RACE`, "
N:", `n`, "
Avg. Scores:", round(mean, digits = 2), "
95% CI:[", round((mean-2.58*se), digits = 2), ",", round((mean+2.58*se), digits = 2),"]")), stat="identity", color="red", size = 1.5, alpha=1) + xlab("Race") + ylab("Average Scores") + theme_minimal() + theme(axis.text.x = element_text( angle = 45, vjust = 0.5, hjust=1)) + ggtitle("99% Confidence interval of average /
maths scores by race")), tooltip = "text"), DT::datatable(shared_df, rownames = FALSE, class="compact", width="100%", options = list(pageLength = 10, scrollX=T), colnames = c("No. of pupils", "Avg Scores", "Std Dev", "Std Error")) %>% formatRound(columns=c('mean', 'sd', 'se'), digits=2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #using stat_pointinterval() of ggdist #displaying distribution of Math scores by race exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval() + labs( title = "Visualising confidence intervals of mean math score", subtitle = "Mean Point + Multiple-interval plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-On_Exercise_04c_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #function comes with many arguments, for example: exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_pointinterval(.width = 0.95, .point = median, .interval = qi) + labs( title = "Visualising confidence intervals of median math score", subtitle = "Median Point + Multiple-interval plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-On_Exercise_04c_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-4.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #---------------------- #using stat_gradientinterval() of ggdist #displaying distribution of Math score by race exam %>% ggplot(aes(x = RACE, y = MATHS)) + stat_gradientinterval( fill = "skyblue", show.legend = TRUE ) + labs( title = "Visualising confidence intervals of mean math score", subtitle = "Gradient + interval plot") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-On_Exercise_04c_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-5.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #install ungeviz package and launching application in R devtools::install_github("wilkelab/ungeviz") library(ungeviz) #building Hypothetical Outcome Plots (HOPs) ggplot(data = exam, (aes(x = factor(RACE), y = MATHS))) + geom_point(position = position_jitter( height = 0.3, width = 0.05), size = 0.4, color = "#0072B2", alpha = 1/2) + geom_hpline(data = sampler(25, group = RACE), height = 0.6, color = "#D55E00") + theme_bw() + transition_states(.draw, 1, 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](Hands-On_Exercise_04c_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.gif) ::: :::
